The start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and re-startup credits, with soft conditions to rural poor people, who do not have access to credit products. These rural poor people are regarded as 'high risk borrowers' because of their low income. 

With her credit, Nargiz will purchase a car. Her husband will drive it as a taxi to transport local people and the family will increase their monthly income. The new business initiative, financed with the Kiva start-up loan, will significantly improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.use: to purchase a car for her husband to drive as a taxi.

loans.name: Tiessiri V Group

texts.fr:
Les dix  membres du groupe TIESSIRI V sont des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 37 ans et ont en moyenne 3 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à Kenikela un des villages de la commune de massigui,  préfecture de Dioîla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de micro finance Soro yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités en début d’hivernage. Les spéculations cultivées sont entre autres l’arachide, du riz et  un peu de mil. Elles sont à leur septième  collaboration avec l’institution.
Avec ce prêt,   KADIATOU SOKOURALA la première personne à gauche dans le rang des débous, compte acheter les intrants, les petits équipements et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir environs 2 Ha de riz et d’arachide 
Les productions sont vendues au niveau de la ville de Massigui, après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. Elle réalise un bénéfice  de 75 000F CFA environs par campagne.
texts.en:
The 10 members of the Tiessiri V Group are married women who average 37 years of age and have an average of three children each. For the most part, they live in polygamous families in Kenikela, a village in Massigui Commune, Dioila prefecture, in the Koulikoro region (Mali's second administrative region).

The women in this group are working with microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso with the goal of being able to better organize their businesses at the beginning of the rainy season. The crops being grown are, among others, ground nuts, rice, and a small amount of millet. The group is on its seventh loan with Soro Yiriwaso.

With this loan, Kadiatou Sokourala (the first person on the left in the row that is standing in the photo) plans to purchase farm inputs and minor equipment, as well as to pay the labor costs to maintain roughly two hectares of rice and groundnuts.

After the harvest, the crops will be sold in the city of Massigui to a customer base of men and women. Kadiatou Sokourala makes a profit of approximately 75,000 CFA francs per loan.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizer, herbicide, and minor equipment, and to pay for plowing and weeding.

loans.name: Tiessiri Iii Group

texts.fr:
Les dix membres du groupe TIESSIRI III sont des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 40 ans et ont en moyenne 4 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à Baba un des villages de la commune de massigui,  préfecture de Dioîla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de micro finance Soro yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités en début d’hivernage. Les spéculations cultivées sont entre autres (Culture de l’arachide, du riz et  un peu de mil). Elles sont à leur septième  collaboration avec l’institution.
Avec ce prêt, Yayi  la personne au milieu dans le rang des assises, compte acheter les intrants, les petits équipements et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir environs 1 ha de riz et d’arachide 
Les productions sont vendues au niveau de la ville de Massigui, après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. Elle réalise un bénéfice  de 45 000F CFA environs par campagne.
texts.en:
The ten members of the group "TIESSIRI  III" are married women averaging 40 years of age and four children each. The women live for the most part in polygamous families in Baba, a village in Commune de Massigui, in Préfecture de Dioîla, Région de Koulikoro (2nd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They are collaborating with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso with the goal of organizing their work better at the start of the rainy season. The crops grown include peanuts, rice, and some millet. The women are in their seventh collaboration with the institution.

With this loan, Yayi, who is sitting in the middle in the photo, intends to purchase farm inputs and sundry equipment and to pay for plowing for maintaining about 1 hectare of rice and peanuts.

After the harvest, the produce is sold in Massigui City to a customer base composed of men and women. She envisions making a profit of about 45,000 francs CFA per planting.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, manure, herbicide, and sundry equipment and to pay for plowing and weeding

loans.name: Inoussa

texts.fr: Inoussa âgé de 37 ans, est marié à une marchande du nom de Odette. Le couple a un enfant, scolarisé et à leur charge. Inoussa vit ensemble avec sa femme et son enfant. Inoussa et sa femme assurent ensemble les diverses charges du ménage. Inoussa n’a fréquenté l'école mais a appris la couture. Inoussa exerce cette activité depuis plus de dix ans. En vue de renforcer ses équipements pour mieux satisfaire la demande de sa clientèle, Inoussa  désire acquérir une nouvelle machine à broder. Pour ce faire, Inoussa sollicite pour la troisième fois, l'appui financier de ALIDé. Les prêts antérieurs ont été bien remboursés.
texts.en: Inoussa, aged 37, is married to a merchant named Odette. The couple have one child, in school and in their care. Inoussa lives together with his wife and child. They jointly ensure that the diverse household expenses are covered. Inoussa did not attend school but learned how to sew. He has been in this business for over ten years.  With the aim of bolstering his equipment to satisfy his customers further, Inoussa would like to acquire a new embroidering machine. To do so, he is requesting for a third time financial support from ALIDé. The previous loans were indeed paid back.

loans.use: to purchase an embroidering machine

loans.name: Glenn

texts.en:
Glenn is a fisherman from the town of Bien Unido, Bohol. Glenn is a married man and a father of six children. He has been in the fishing business for more than 10 years now. This is the source of his income.

Glenn is asking for a loan to buy a new engine for the fishing boat. With this, he will be able to improve his fishing business as well as his income. In the future, Glenn hopes to make his business a success and a sustainable source of income.

loans.use: to buy a new engine for the fishing boat.

loans.name: Mundo De Fe Group

texts.es: Grupo formado por cuatro socias emprendedoras una de ellas es Patricia tiene 28 años de edad, soltera, su negocio es la venta de comida y refrescos naturales. Tiene un año de experiencia en el negocio, el crédito lo invertirá en la  compra de materia prima como arroz, azúcar, carne de res, carne de pollo, frijoles crudos, frutas como papaya, naranja dulce, melón, granadilla etc. Marbeli tiene 25 años de edad y su negocio es una pulpería, Flor tiene 25 años de edad y su negocio es la venta de comida y Elena tiene 31 años de edad y su negocio es la venta de comida y ropa nueva
texts.en:
The group is comprised of four enterprising members.  Patricia, age 28, is one of them.  She is single, and her business is selling food and natural soft drinks.  She has one year of experience in the business.  She will use the loan to buy raw material like rice, sugar, beef, chicken, uncooked beans, and fruit like papaya, oranges, melon, and passion fruit, etc.

Marbeli, age 25, has a grocery store business.  Flor, age 25, sells food.  Elena, age 31, has a business selling food and new clothes.

loans.use: to buy raw material like rice, sugar, beef, chicken, uncooked beans, and fruit like papaya, oranges, melon, and passion fruit, etc.

loans.name: Banex

texts.en:
Banex, a married young man of 25 years, with one child, is from a humble background. He did not go far with school because his parents could not afford to pay his high school tuition. However, he got lucky because he recently found a contract job as a casual laborer with the construction firm working on the road leading to his town. He thinks that he will be able to save some of his wages to pay the monthly installments of the loan that he is using to pay for a piece of land.

He hopes to start making bricks after buying the plot of land, so that he can put up a shelter for his young family very soon. Banex is a hard-working, young man who wants to work hard, so that he can provide the best for his child, especially in terms of education. 

Banex is standing in the center, between his parents on the left and his wife and credit officer on the right. They all consented to the photo and signed the waiver form.

loans.use: To pay for a plot of land.

loans.name: Siem

texts.en:
Siem, 44 years old, is a resident living with her spouse and three children in her own home in Kompong Cham province. She works in agriculture, specifically in the cultivation of rice, cassava and sugar cane trees on around two hectares of farmland. 

She has been operating in this field for many years and has gained a lot of valuable experience, which allows her to obtain better yields. She usually sells her products in all the surrounding areas and markets of the regions, together with her husband generating approximately a net income of USD 8.00 per day.

Siem needs to invest in the purchase of farm supplies, such as sugar cane trees and cassava for seeding. Due to insufficient capital for the investment, she is asking for a Kiva loan amounting to USD 1,400. She has confidence to pay off her loan on time, and at the same time she can supply her family with the basic living necessities.

loans.use: to purchase farm supplies.

loans.name: Gbo-Tima Group

texts.en:
In the photo are members of the Gbo-Tima Group. They are small-scale businesswomen, based in Waterloo, a town in western Sierra Leone. This is the first loan these entrepreneurs are accessing from Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT)/Kiva lenders. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more profit, and consequently improve on their standards of living. 

The featured leader of this group is Fatmata. Fatmata is age 30. She was born in Moyamba. However, she is currently residing in Waterloo, together with her husband and five children. Her husband is a military officer and four of her children are attending either primary or secondary schools. 

For five years now, Fatmata has been selling market-food – palm-oil, onions, margi (used to give sauce a sweet taste), salt, pepper, etc. With this loan, she is going to buy palm-oil, onions, margi, salt, pepper, etc., in bulk, to add to her current stock.

loans.use: to buy palm-oil, onions, margi, salt, and pepper, etc., in bulk, to add to her current stock.

loans.name: Elineo

texts.en: Elineo is a thirty four year old married man with two children living in Fort Portal, Uganda. His main business is running a cosmetics shop alongside a barber shop to boost his income. Having a bigger, well-stocked shop and the ability to provide fully for his family is his greatest dream. Elineo is requesting a loan to buy cosmetics to sell.

loans.use: to buy cosmetics to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy palm oil, onions, margi, salt, pepper, etc. in bulk to add to her current stock.

loans.name: Cheryl

texts.en:
Cheryl is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a business selling spare parts in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 11,000 through Kiva partner NWTF in order to purchase more spare parts to sell to her customers.

Cheryl successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her business.

NWTF is re-listing Cheryl's business profile again in support of her efforts to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase more spare parts to sell to customers.

loans.name: Salvacion

texts.en:
Salvacion is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a rice selling business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 27,000 through Kiva partner NWTF in order to purchase more stock to sell to customers.

Salvacion successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her business.

NWTF is re-listing Salvacion's business profile again in support of her efforts to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of cereals to sell.

loans.name: Wilfred

texts.en: Wilfred used the previous loan to buy cocoa to sell. He is a forty-two year old hardworking farmer living in Bundibugyo, Uganda. He grows cocoa and also buys cocoa from other farmers to sell. He has operated his business for over five years. Like most farmers, he faces the challenge of inadequate capital to buy necessary farm inputs, coupled with price fluctuation. Nevertheless, his dream is to become the leading cocoa supplier in the district. Wilfred intends to use the loan to buy cocoa to sell and rehabilitate his farm by buying fertilizers to apply.

loans.use: to buy cocoa to sell and fertilizers to apply.

loans.name: Tatay-Yirra Group

texts.en:
Fatmata is the featured leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Fatmata was born in Makeni city, 30 years ago. She is married to a house builder and the couple has five children, four of whom are attending primary and secondary schools respectively. 

For 13 years now, Fatmata has been selling napkins, pants, towels, wrappers, baby clothes, etc. This is the first loan that Fatmata and her group members have applied for from SMT/Kiva lenders. With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their respective businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions. Fatmata will use her share of the loan (SLL 500,000) in order to expand her business by buying the above mentioned items in bulk to add to her current stock.

loans.use: to buy napkins, pants, towels, wrappers, baby clothes, etc. in bulk to add to her current stock.

loans.name: With Out Money Group

texts.en:
In the photo are members of the “Without Money” group. They are small scale business people based in Waterloo, a town in western Sierra Leone. This is the first loan these entrepreneurs are accessing from SMT/Kiva lenders. With this loan, they will be able to expand their respective businesses, make more profits and consequently improve their standard of living. 

The featured leader of this group is Hawa. Hawa is aged 49-years-old and she was born in Magburaka town but is currently residing in Waterloo, together with her husband and three children. Her husband is a fisherman and  her children are attending primary and secondary schools. For eight years now, Hawa has been selling fish. With this current loan, Hawa will buy a larger quantity of fish to add to her current stock.

loans.use: to buy a larger quantity of fish to add to her current stock.

loans.name: Juan Francisco

texts.es: Juan de 34 años de edad vive en casa propia con su esposa y sus tres hijos, es empleado trabaja de analista en una empresa que está cerca de su lugar de residencia  tiene varios años de trabajar en esa actividad con el pago que recibe logra solventar algunos gastos de su hogar, Juan esta solicitando un crédito para la compra de una turbo cocina ecológica y asi poder ahorrarse algunos gastos en su hogar con la inversión de la compra de la cocina.
texts.en: Juan, age 34, lives in his own home with his wife and three children. He is employed and works as an analyst for a company located near to his home. He has worked there for several years, and is able to cover some household costs with his income. Juan is requesting a loan for the purchase of a turbo cooker so that he can save on some household costs with this investment.

loans.use: to buy a turbo cooker.

loans.name: Iman

texts.en:
Iman, 35 years old, is from Gaza. She is married and has four children, three of whom attend primary school.

She has owned a place for sewing and selling embroidery since 2005 and she has one employee.

She asked Ryada for this loan in order to buy sewing machines for her embroidery workshop .She hopes that this loan will increase the productivity of the project,, thus improving her family's financial situation so she can approach her dreaming of having a big workshop,

loans.use: to buy sewing machines for her embroidery workshop

loans.name: Charles

texts.en: Charles is a forty-eight year old married man with ten children living in Kasese, Uganda. He runs a retail business and with the proceeds, he has been able to educate his children. He hopes to educate his children to a university level and trade in wholesale. Charles is requesting a loan to buy soda, soap and sugar to sell.

loans.use: to buy soda, soap and sugar to sell.

loans.name: Hamid

texts.en: Hamid is a 29-year-old married man who lives with his child in Sana`a, Yemen. He has owned a butcher shop for five years. He started off by working in a restaurant and eventually accumulated money and opened his own butcher shop. He is a hardworking man who treats his customers politely.  Because he wants money to purchase products for his store, he has asked for a loan of 150,000 YER from Al-Amal Microfinance Bank (AMB) to buy meat for resale to his clients. He hopes to improve his family's living conditions and become a merchant.

loans.use: to buy meat for resale to his clients.

loans.name: Cecile

texts.en:
Cecile is 32 years old and single.

Cecile is in the agricultural business farming rice in the Philippines. Cecile requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies.

Cecile has been farming rice for 10 years now and has borrowed six times in the past from NWTF to sustain the business.

In the future, Cecile would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies.

loans.name: Butukuru Bakyara Tweyimukye Group

texts.en: Peluce is a hardworking lady living in Fort Portal, Uganda. She practices agriculture and with the profits from her business she has been able to buy fertilizers and more land for farming. She has a vision of expanding and diversifying her business to include dairy farming, although she is faced with the hardships of unpredictable weather changes and price fluctuations. Peluce will use the loan to buy maize seedlings for planting. She is a member of the above mentioned group where each one guarantees the other in accessing the loan.

loans.use: to buy maize seedlings for planting.

loans.name: Oun

texts.en:
Oun is thirty-four years old, and a married woman of three children that live with her in a small home in Kompong Cham province. Oun is a farmer, which is why she owns a few pieces of land where she and her husband help each other by sowing rice for nourishing the family and for sale. She focuses more on his crops, because it is the sole source of her family income. Her business location is very well-suited to rice, cassava, other seasonal crops, and that’s why she always tries to keep her land fertile and her crops in good condition. 

Oun has been working in this occupation for almost 20 years. This is her third HKL loan and first Kiva loan, which she will use to buy extra farmland to increase her annual rice production. She is very delighted and grateful for the financial support she receives to keep her business growing.

loans.use: to buy extra farmland.

loans.name: Clarita

texts.en:
Clarita is 39 years old, married and has two children. She is working hard to provide the educational needs of her children.  At the moment, she is engaged in the food vending business where she sells halo-halo (is a popular Filipino dessert that is a mixture of shaved ice and evaporated milk to which are added various boiled sweet beans and fruits and served in a tall glass or bowl) and other beverages for refreshment in their village.

She wants to buy more ingredients and improve her income, which is why she is asking for a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy milk and different ingredients such as bananas, sweet potatoes and beans for her halo-halo business.  She hopes that her business will become successful.

loans.use: to buy milk, bananas and potatoes to cook and sell

loans.name: Flaviano

texts.en: Flaviano is a 55 year old married man from Talibon, Bohol. He has 4 grown children. Growing seaweed is the family's source of income. He has been farming seaweed for more than 10 years now. Flaviano has requested a loan of 30,000 PHP to buy more seaweed seedlings and materials like straw, tissue and bamboo sticks to increase the harvest. In the future, Flaviano  hopes that he can expand his seaweed farming business to improve his family’s standard of living.

loans.use: to buy more seaweed seedlings and materials like straw, tissue and bamboo sticks

loans.name: Rosalia

texts.en: Rosalia is a 50 year old married woman from Talibon, Bohol. She has 5 children.The oldest child is 30 while the youngest is 20. Rosalia has been raising pigs for almost 2 years. She requested a loan of 5,000 PHP to buy additional pigs and feed, in order to produce healthy pigs that can be sold on time. In the future, Rosalia would like to expand her hog raising business to improve her standard of living and to provide her family with good food.

loans.use: to buy additional pigs and feed

loans.name: Dawood

texts.en: Dawood is 24 years old and lives in Taiz, Yemen. He has been operating a business selling batteries and oils for six months. He is able to attract many clients. He acquired his experience when he worked in other batteries and oils businesses. He accumulated some money to start up this business. He is a hardworking man who tries to offer a good life for his family. He would like to expand his business, so he has applied for a loan of 200,000 YER from AMB to buy more batteries and oils for his business. He hopes to open an extra store in the same field.

loans.use: to buy batteries and oils for his business.

loans.name: Bonface

texts.en:
Bonface is a 35-year-old man in the motorcycle transport business. He is married with four children. His motorcycle business is based in Nairobi, Kenya, and he has run it for the past five years. According to him, the business has been profitable. 

This will be Bonface's fourth loan term with KADET LTD, and he plans to use the funds to buy an extra motorcycle. With that, Bonface will be able to make more income, with which he will buy a plot and build a house for his family.

In the future, Bonface hopes to buy more motorcycles and be successful in the transport business, and thus be able to provide for the needs of his family.

loans.use: to buy a motorcycle.

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles is a 54-year-old mechanic who sells spare motorcycle and bicycle parts, as well as seat belts for passenger service vehicles. He is a married man with four children and has been in this business for the last ten years doing well. 

This marks his second loan from KADET LTD, Kiva's partner, to finance his business. Charles will use the loan to purchase more spare motorcycle and bicycle spare parts for his shop, and the anticipated profit from the loan will help him expand his business. He hopes to have a stable and profitable business in the future.

loans.use: to purchase spare motorcycle and bicycle parts for his shop.

loans.name: Amos

texts.en:
Amos is a 58-year-old married man with ten children and four dependents who are grandsons from his late son. He was previously a civil servant, but with time and as the children started going to higher institutions of learning, the small salary was inadequate to cater to their financial needs. So, he decided to retire to practice commercial farming of coffee, since he had an averagely big piece of land. 

Income from the coffee sales has helped him a lot in educating his children. Amos attributes this to hard work and determination. Having bore many children, he had to struggle a lot to see them get a good education. 

Amos narrates that his coffee plantation has been a savior in his financial needs. He has requested a loan of UGX 1,000,000 to complete tuition for his two sons at university, since this is their final year. If his plan is fulfilled, Amos projects a harvest of 15 coffee bags next season, which will enable him to pay up the loan, finish his house that is under construction and pay tuition for his other children.

loans.use: to pay tuition for his two sons who are at university.

loans.name: Amor Al Trabajo Group

texts.es: Grupo formado por cuatros socios emprendedores una de ella  es Karla tiene  32 años de edad, con un hijo, casada, su negocio es de una pulpería ubicada en su domicilio, tiene un año de tener su negocio, este crédito  lo  invertirá en la compra de inventario como granos como arroz, frijoles, azúcar, aceite, sal, pan, pan dulce, carne de res, carne de pollo, productos lácteos, medicamentos populares, maizenas, caramelos, gaseosas, jugo en latas, jugo en cajas, jabon de baño, jabon de lavar, ace, cloro,  Arlinn tiene 24 años de edad y su negocio es la venta de productos básicos, Rosa es otra socia  tiene 44 años y su  negocio es  la venta de nacatamales y Jose tiene 47 años y su negocio es la compra de cosechas de tamarindo.Agradecida con los inversionistas de Kiva por el apoyo brindado atraves del credito, lo que a logrado es que maneja una variedad de productos en inventarios.
texts.en:
This group is made up of four enterprising members. One of them is Karla. She is 32 and married with one child. Her business is a grocery store located in her home, which she has had for a year. She will use this loan to invest in buying inventory, such as rice, beans, sugar, oil, salt, bread, sweet bread, chicken, dairy products, popular medicines, corn flour, candies, sodas,  canned juices, juice cartons, washing soap, detergent, bleach, etc. 

Arlin is 24 and her business is selling basic products. Another member, Rosa, is 44 and her business is selling nacatamales. Jose is 47 and his business is buying tamarind crops.

Thanks to Kiva investors for the support they have given through their loans, the group has achieved an ability to include a variety of products in their inventories.

loans.use: to invest in buying rice, beans, sugar, oil, salt, bread, sweet bread, chicken, dairy products, popular medicines, corn flour, caramels, sodas,  canned juices, boxed juices, washing soap, detergent, bleach, etc.

loans.name: Essivi

texts.fr: Essivi a pour conjoint un éleveur. Elle a 02 enfants âgés de 23 et 02ans. Pour contribuer aux besoins de la famille, elle revend des poissons fumés de façon ambulante depuis 2003. Le prêt sollicité de WAGES l’aidera à acheter plus de marchandises. A l’avenir, elle espère développer son activité et assurer l’éducation de la famille. Elle est âgée de 43ans.
texts.en: Essivi is married to a farmer. She has two children, who are 23 and 2 years of age. To help provide for her family, she has worked reselling smoked fish on the street since 2003. She has requested a loan from WAGES to help her buy more merchandise. In the future, Essivi hopes to develop her business and provide for her children's education. She is 43 years old.

loans.use: to buy smoked fish

loans.name: Isolina Del Carmen

texts.es:
Isolina del Carmen una Joven emprendedora de 21 años de edad, soltera y sin hijos, viven en una comarca de Chinandega, vive en casa de sus padres, estudiante universitaria de contabilidad casi al finalizar sus estudios, desea tener su ´propio negocio como es un tienda surtida, con la iniciativa juvenil para jóvenes emprendedoras es la oportunidad para poder realizar sus sueños como es tener su tienda, ella inicio a vender de forma ambulante con su mamá desde los 15 años, adquirió experiencia por lo cual se independizo a los 17 años de edad y hoy en día tiene muchos clientes para satisfacer la demanda necesita un financiamiento que le ayude a tener su propio negocio y no andar ofreciendo ambulante, ya que de esto ella mantiene sus estudios. 

es una joven con una visión amplia, segura de lo que quiere con muchos deseos de crecer, responsable, honesta y muy trabajadora, necesita un crédito para invertir y surtir su negocio y obtener sus propias ganancias.
texts.en:
Isolina del Carmen, 21, is an enterprising young woman.  She's single and has no children.  She lives in her parents's house in a region of Chinandega.  She studies accounting in the university and is about to finish her program.

She wants to have her own business, a stocked store.  With youthful initiative for young entrepreneurs, it's her opportunity to be able to achieve her dreams, such as having a store.

She started selling on foot with her mother when she was 15.  She acquired experience and went out on her own when she was 17.  Today she has a lot of customers.  To satisfy the demand she needs a loan, which will help her have her own business and not sell on foot, because this is how she supports her studies.

She's a young woman with a broad vision, sure of what she wants and with a great desire to grow.  She's responsible, honest, and very hardworking.  She needs a loan to invest and stock her business to earn her own income.

loans.use: to buy clothing, shoes, jewelry, and appliances

loans.name: Las Lomas De San Juan Group

texts.es: Elva de 41 años es casada y tiene 02 hijos aún dependientes, ella es integrante del grupo “Las Lomas De San Juan” conformada por 10 socios empeñosos que han demostrado ser responsables. Elva es la que preside al grupo, cargo que ha llevado con responsabilidad. Actualmente se dedica a la venta de comidas, la cual lo realiza a repartos. Con el crédito anterior pudo implementar su negocio. Su reciente crédito lo destinará para la compra de insumos como arroz, azúcar, fideos, leche, entre otros productos. El deseo de Elva es de poner su restaurante, pues así asegura ella tendrá mayores ganancias. El grupo “Las Lomas De San Juan” agradecen el crédito brindado y se comprometen a seguir trabajando bien. Elva se encuentra en la parte posterior es la tercera del lado izquierdo y chompa a rayas.
texts.en: Elva, 41, is married and has 2 children who are still dependents.  She is a member of the communal bank "Las Lomas De San Juan."  This group has 10 hardworking members who have shown themselves to be responsible.  Elva is the leader of the group, a role that she carries out with responsibility.  She now has a business selling food which she delivers to her customers.  With the last loan, she was able to set up her business.  This loan will be used to buy supplies, such as rice, sugar, noodles, milk, and other products.  Elva wants to start up a restaurant, because this way she is sure that she would have greater earnings.    The communal bank "Las Lomas De San Juan" is grateful for the loan that is being provided to them, and they promise to continue to work hard.  In the picture, Elva is the third from the left in the back, wearing the striped sweater.

loans.use: to buy rice, sugar, noodles and milk

loans.name: Abu Bakarr's Group

texts.en:
Pictured here are primary school teachers from the town of Waterloo, near Freetown, Sierra Leone’s capital city. This group of teachers has come to SMT, a partner of Kiva.org base in Makeni, to apply for a loan of SLL 10,500,000.00 for the entire team in order to meet their most immediate and most pressing financial needs. At the end of each month, they can easily repay the loan using their monthly salaries. It is their school’s bursar who is directly responsible for taking the deductions and making the repayments on their behalf.

Abu Bakarr is the name of the featured leader of this team. A native of Freetown, the 45-year-old is married to a teacher and the couple has 4 school aged kids. Abu Bakarr has been a school teacher for many years now. He has requested this loan in order to buy house building materials like iron corrugated sheets for the construction of a dwelling house.

loans.use: to buy house building materials like iron and corrugated sheets for the construction of a dwelling house

loans.name: Kisanga K Group

texts.en:
SALMA who is in her mid 30s is a divorcee with three children who are still going to school. She has been a food vendor for one and a half years now.  She works from 6.00 pm to 10.30 pm daily and is able to make a good monthly profit.

This will be SALMA's 2nd loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loan to increase the capital so she could restock the missing items in her food store. She has paid back her loan successfully. She used the profit to cover household expenses and pay school fees. She will use this loan to buy more food to sell to more customers. She dreams of owning a Hotel.

Salma will share this loan with her loan group "KISANGA K" which has twelve members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy more food to sell to more customers.

loans.name: Peninah

texts.en: Peninah lives in Malindi, Kenya. She has been running a grocery store for the last three years. She found out about Milango through friends at a time when she really needed credit for her store. The 23-year-old mother of two seeks a loan to buy tomatoes, kale, bananas and avocados for resale. Major challenges that she has experienced in the business include competition and price changes. Her primary aim of doing business is helping her husband make their life better in the future. Her ambition is to own a bigger shop in the future.

loans.use: to buy tomatoes, kale, bananas and avocados

loans.name: Irine

texts.en:
39-year-old Irine lives alone with her 13-year-old son in the Kutaisi district. Irine requested loan from local financial institutions several times for family business start-up, but without any success. Her loan request was rejected all the time because of her low income and her family’s poor living conditions. 

The only source of the income for the family is Irine’s monthly salary. She is working as a accountant assistant. 
Irine requested loan from Credo to start-up a family business. Irine has now been approved for a loan within the framework of the new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program helps provide business, start-up, and re-startup credits with soft conditions to rural poor people, who do not have access to credit opportunities. These rural poor people are regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of their low income.

With her credit Irine will trade curtains from Turkey. She will go to Turkey to purchase at the wholesale price, bring the curtains back to her district and sell them among the villagers for a profit. This will give Irine an opportunity to increase her monthly income. With this increased income she will be to improve the living conditions for her family and insure a better life for her son.

loans.use: To buy curtains from Turkey for resale

loans.name: Na God Dae Gee Ii Group

texts.en:
Meet with members of the “Na God Dae Gee II” Group from Koidu, a city in eastern Sierra Leone. They are all local entrepreneurs who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva, to apply for a loan of 500,000 leones each. With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their respective businesses, make more sales, and consequently improve their living conditions.

Sia is the featured leader of this group. This 34-year-old is married to a diamond miner, and together they have three children, two of whom are attending primary schools. Sia has been a businesswoman for five years now. She sells market food (tomatoes, etc.) With her share of this loan, she will buy the above mentioned items in bulk to add to her current stock.

loans.use: to buy tomatoes, etc., in bulk  to add to her current stock

loans.name: Ilgar

texts.ru:
Ilgar chestniy i spravedliviy muj i otec troix detey. U nego 2 sinovey i odna dochka kotoraya skoro vixodit zamuj. Dla togo chtobi kupit ey pridanogo kak i pologaetsa mestnim obichayam, Ilgaru ponadobilos 1600 AZN. Na etu summu on priobretet stiralnuyu mashinu i xolodilnik. 
Ilgar fermer s 30 letnim stajem, on xorosho razbiraetsa v proizvodstve molochnix produktov i drugix selskozoyastvenniix tovarov. Krome etogo on na sobstvennom traktore pashet zemlnie uchastki za opredelennuyu summu.
texts.en:
Ilgar is an honest and fair man. He is married and has three children. He has two sons as well as a daughter who is soon to be married. In order to pay her dowry in accordance with the local custom, Ilgar needs 1600 AZN. He will use this money to buy a washing machine and a refrigerator.
Ilgar is a farmer with 30 years of work experience. He knows about producing dairy products and other farm produce. In addition, he has his own tractor and works for hire plowing other people’s land.

loans.use: to purchase a refrigerator and a washing machine as his daughter's dowry.

loans.name: Mahugnon 4 Group

texts.fr: MAHUGNON 4 est un groupe de trois personnes, dont les membres sont des amies et ont un lien de parenté. La représentante du groupe, nommée Kanon Lydie (celle qui a la main levée sur la photo) est âgée de 38 ans. Kanon Lydie n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Kanon Lydie est mariée à un chauffeur du nom de Waliou. Le couple a quatre enfants, dont certains scolarisés et trois à leur charge. Kanon Lydie vit avec son mari et ses enfants. Kanon Lydie et son mari assurent ensemble les charges du ménage. Pour ce faire, Kanon Lydie vend du riz à son domicile depuis quinze ans. Kanon Lydie s'approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin. Dans le but de renforcer son activité et de satisfaire la demande de sa clientèle, Kanon Lydie s’associe avec les autres membres du groupe MAHUGNON 4 pour solliciter un cinquième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Les prêts antérieurs ont été bien remboursés.
texts.en:
Mahugnon 4 is a group consisting of three persons, whose members are friends and are related. The representative for the group, Kanon Lydie (the one raising her hand on the photo), is 38 years old.

Kanon Lydie did not attend school. She is married to a driver named Waliou. The couple has four children, some of whom attend school and three are dependents. Kanon Lydie lives with her ​​husband and her children. and shares all household expenses with her husband.

To do this, Kanon Lydie has been selling rice at home for the past fifteen years. She gets her supplies from one of Benin's markets.

To strengthen her business and meet with customer demand, Kanon Lydie and the other members of the Mahugnon 4 group are requesting a fifth loan from ALIDé. Previous loans have been correctly repaid.

loans.use: buy rice and condiments

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is 31 years old and married with two children. He has a butchery shop in Kangundo town and has been in this business for the past three and a half years. Besides selling raw meat, he also cooks fried and boiled meat, which his customers come to eat at the same place.

This is John's first loan term from KADET Ltd. and he plans to buy more furniture. This includes tables and chairs so that he can accommodate and serve more customers who come to eat meat. He also plans to buy more stock of meat and, thereby, have enough stock to sell. He will use the anticipated income to venture into dairy farming and sell milk as well. He hopes to be successful in his business, make more income, and be able to provide for the needs of his family.

loans.use: To buy furniture, equipment and more stock of meat.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy palm oil, onions, Margi, salt, pepper, etc., in bulk to add to her current stock

loans.name: Luz Del Día Group

texts.es: Yolanda tiene 27 años es madre de un niño el cual estudia el preescolar ella pertenece al grupo llamado Luz del Día dice que una tía al invito porque la vio triste porque entre su esposo y ella no podían juntar para comprar las refacciones de una combi de transporte público y es por eso que le dijo su tía que entrara a trabajar con VisionFund para que pudiera tener en mejores condiciones la combi, ella vive en una población conocida como uno de los principales productores de flor de Noche buena a nivel nacional, dice que cuando es temporada de noviembre su esposo se va a hacer fletes a todo el país de esta flor y es cuando mejor le va en el año ya que a diario tiene trabajo el resto del año se dedica a trabajar la combi a diferentes rutas como transporte público. Ahorita Yola como de cariño le dicen está pidiendo un crédito para la compra de refacciones como llantas y el mantenimiento de la combi dice que le ha servido de mucho los créditos que ha pedido porque han mejorado su unidad, además esta ahorrando para comprar otra combi y así darle trabajo a la gente de su comunidad. Las demás integrantes del grupo se llaman Audelia, Leónides, Josefina y Candelaria ellas invertirán sus crédito en una mercería, en la compra de artículos para surtir tienda de abarrotes, en la compra de ropa para damas y niños para su venta y en la compra de macetas, molcajetes y compra de artesanía para su venta.
texts.en:
Yolanda is 27 and is the mother of one child who goes to preschool. She belongs to the group called Luz del Día (Daylight). She says that she was invited by one of her aunts because the aunt saw that she was unhappy when between herself and her spouse they were unable to get together enough money to buy parts for a minibus used for public transport. For this reason her aunt suggested that she start to work with VisionFund so that they would be able to keep their minibus in better condition. 

She lives in a town that is known nationally as one of the main producers of poinsettias. She says that seasonally when it is November, her husband goes off to make deliveries of this flower  throughout the country and this is the best time of the year for him because he has daily work. During the rest of the year he occupies himsef by working different routes with the minibus as public transport. Currently Yola, as her friends call her, is looking for a loan in order to purchase spare parts like tires and to perform maintenance on the minibus.

She says that the previous loans that she has taken out have helped her a lot because they have improved her family unit. In addition, she is saving to buy another minibus and in this way provide work for the people in her community.

The other members of the group are named Audelia, Leónides, Josefina and Candelaria. They will invest their loan in a notions store, to purchase articles to stock a grocery store, to purchase women's and children's clothes to sell and to purchase flowerpots, mortars and crafts to sell.

loans.use: to buy parts and provide maintenance for a minibus used for public transport.

loans.name: Djidjoho 2 Group

texts.fr: DJIDJOHO 2 est un groupe de trois personnes, dont les membres sont des amies et qui appartiennent à un même groupe de tontine. La représentante du groupe, nommée Yémalin Armandine(celle qui a la main levée sur la photo) est âgée de 38 ans. Yémalin Armandine n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Yémalin Armandine est mariée à un certain Isidore. Le couple a deux enfants, tous scolarisés et à leur charge. Yémalin Armandine vit avec son mari et ses enfants. Le couple assure ensemble les charges du ménage. Pour ce faire, Yémalin Armandine vend du riz accompagné de sauce à son domicile depuis dix-huit ans. De façon secondaire, Yémalin Armandine vend des liqueurs, ce qui lui permet d'avoir d'autres sources de revenus. Yémalin Armandine s'approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin. Dans le but de renforcer son activité et de satisfaire la demande de sa clientèle, Yémalin Armandine s’associe avec les autres membres du groupe DJIDJOHO 2 pour solliciter un quatrième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Les prêts antérieurs ont été bien remboursés.
texts.en:
DJIDJOHO 2 is a group consisting of three persons, whose members are friends and belong to the same tontine (loan association) group. The representative for the group, Yémalin Armandine (the one raising her hand on the photo) is 38 years old. 

Yémalin Armandine did not attend school. She is married to Isidore. The couple has two children; both attend school and are dependents. Yémalin Armandine lives with her ​​husband and children, and the couple shares household expenses.

To do this, Yémalin Armandine has been selling rice with sauce from her home for the past eighteen years. Secondarily, she sells liqueurs, which enables her to have other sources of income. She resupplies in one of Benin's markets.

To strengthen her business and meet with customer demand, Yémalin Armandine and the other members of the DJIDJOHO 2 group are requesting a fourth loan from ALIDé. Previous loans have been fully repaid.

loans.use: buy rice, condiments and liqueurs

loans.name: Komla

texts.fr: Mr Komla vit avec sa femme et leurs 04 enfants tous scolarisés à Lomé. Chauffeur de profession, il est également propriétaire de maison et sollicite un premier crédit à WAGES pour la réfection du toit. Après la réfection, il espère louer pour tirer plus de bénéfice. Il veut construire d’autres chambres et assurer l’éducation de ses enfants. Komla est âgé de 51ans.
texts.en:
Mr. Komla lives with his wife and their four children, all of whom attend school in Lome. A driver by profession, he also owns a house and is requesting a first credit loan from WAGES for roof repairs.

After repairs are completed he hopes to rent the house to generate more profit. He wants to build more rooms and ensure his children's education. Komla is 51 years old.

loans.use: repair his house

loans.name: José Ángel

texts.es:
José tiene 54 años de edad, es casado y tiene tres hijos. Aprendo a trabajar la tierra a temprana edad ayudando a su padre y a sus hermanos a cultivar la tierra desde entonces se he dedicado al trabajo de la agricultura y ganadería. Por ese motivo,  posee mucha experiencia en su trabajo ya que por muchos años a sido el sustento suyo y de su familia. El abono, fertilizantes, entre otros insumos,  los compra en la ciudad mas cerca que se encuentra a 30 minutos de su lugar de residencia, se traslada en un autobús que pasa solo una vez al día y debe estar pendiente de la hora; para salir esperar el autobús tiene que caminar unos 15 minutos, sus hijos deben tener lista la carreta para llevar los sacos para la casa.  

El préstamo que esta solicitando a Fundación Campo, es para comprar semilla, fertilizantes, abono, herbicidas, pesticidas, para cultivar. De esta manera, cubrirá las necesidades de su hogar con las ganancias que le deje la venta de la cosecha y ahorrar un poco para la próxima siembra. Su propósito es, cultivar más cantidad de terreno, mejorando la calidad de vida de su familia.
texts.en:
José, 54, is married and has three children.  He learned to farm at a young age, helping his father and his siblings cultivate the land.  Since then he has worked in agriculture and livestock.  This is why he has a lot of experience in his job, which for many years has been his support and that of his family.

He buys soil amendments, fertilizer, and other inputs in the closest city, about 30 minutes from his house.  He takes a bus that goes by only once a day, so he has to pay attention to the time.  To go out and wait for the bus he has to walk some 15 minutes.  His children have the cart ready to carry the sacks to the house.

The loan he's requesting from Fundación Campo is to buy seed, fertilizer, soil amendments, herbicide, and pesticide for the crops.  This way he'll cover his household needs with the profits from the sale of the harvest and save a little money for the next planting.

His goal is to cultivate more land to improve his family's quality of life.

loans.use: to buy seed and agricultural supplies

loans.name: Voces Unidas Group

texts.es: Grupo formado por tres socias emprendedora, una de ella es María mujer de 48 años de edad, soltera, con un hijo, su negocio es la venta de hojuelas, espumias las vende ambulante en su comunidad, esta actividad tiene de hacerlo más de 32 años, este crédito lo invertirá en materia prima como harina, azúcar, canela, huevos, colorantes, bolsas plásticas etc. Marisol tiene 44 años y su negocio es la venta de nacatamales y Escolástica tiene 56 años de edad y su negocio es la venta de artesanía típica.
texts.en:
This group is made of three enterprising members.  One of them is María, a 48-year-old woman who is single and has one son.  Her business is the sale of puff pastries and meringues, which she sells as a street vendor.  She has done this job for more than 32 years.  She will invest this loan in raw materials like flour, sugar, cinnamon, eggs, food coloring, plastic bags, etc.  

Marisol is 44 years old and her business is the sale of nacamatales (a traditional dish similar to tamales).  Escolástica is 56 years old and her business is the sale of traditional crafts.

loans.use: purchase raw materials like flour, sugar, cinnamon, eggs, food coloring, plastic bags, etc.

loans.name: Fassokounawolo  I Group

texts.fr:
Les dix  membres du groupe  FASSOKOUNAWOLO I sont des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 46 ans et ont en moyenne 4 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à Koba un des villages de la commune de Massigui,  préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de micro finance Soro yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités en début d’hivernage. Les spéculations cultivées sont entre autres  l’arachide, du riz et  un peu de mil. Elles sont à leur septième  collaboration avec l’institution.
Avec ce prêt,  Sata Maro la deuxième personne à droite dans le rang des debout, compte acheter les intrants, les petits équipements et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir environs 05 ha de riz et d’arachide 
Les productions sont vendues au niveau de la ville de Massigui, après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice  de 125 000F CFA environs par campagne.
texts.en:
The ten members of the FASSOKOUNAWOLO I group  are married women who on average are 46 years of age with four children. Most of them live in polygamous families in Koba, a village in the municipality of Massigui, part of the Dioïla prefecture belonging to Koulikoro, which is the second administrative region of Mali.

They work with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution in order to better organize their early winter activities. The crops cultivated include groundnuts, rice and a little mil. They are entering their seventh collaboration with the institution.

With this loan Sata Maro, the second person standing from the right, plans to buy inputs, small equipment, and pay for labor to maintain around five hectares (about 12.5 acres)  of rice and groundnuts.

After harvesting, the crops are sold in the town of Massigui, to a clientele composed of men and women. She expects profits of around 125,000 FCFA per growing season.

loans.use: pay for tillage, seed, fertilizer, herbicide, weeding and small equipment

loans.name: Fassokounawolo Ii Group

texts.fr:
Les dix  membres du groupe FASSOKOUNAWOLO II sont  des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 35 ans et ont en moyenne 3 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à Koba un des villages de la commune de Massigui,  préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de micro finance Soro yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités en début d’hivernage. Les spéculations cultivées sont entre autres  l’arachide, du riz et  un peu de mil. Elles sont à leur septième  collaboration avec l’institution.
Avec ce prêt, Mamou Chaka la première  personne à gauche dans le rang des assises, compte acheter les intrants, les petits équipements et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir environs 2 ha de riz et d’arachide 
Les productions sont vendues au niveau de la ville de Massigui, après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice  de 100 000F CFA environs par campagne.
texts.en:
The ten members of the FASSOKOUNAWOLO II group are married women who on average are 35 years of age with three children. Most of them live in polygamous families in Koba, a village in the municipality of Massigui, part of the Dioïla prefecture belonging to Koulikoro, which is the second administrative region of Mali.

They work with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution in order to better organize their early winter activities. The crops cultivated include groundnuts, rice and a little mil. They are entering their seventh collaboration with the institution.

With this loan Mamou Chaka, the first person kneeling on the left, plans to buy inputs, small equipment, and pay for labor to maintain around two hectares (about 5 acres) of rice and groundnuts.

After harvesting, the crops are sold in the town of Massigui, to a clientele composed of men and women. She expects profits of around 100,000 FCFA per growing season.

loans.use: pay for tillage, seed, fertilizer, herbicide, weeding and small equipment.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret lives in Malindi, Kenya. She owns a salon and a barber shop, where she has employed three people. This has been her business since 2007. She is a single mother of one school-going child. She heard of Milango through a group of women she met in her salon. She is employed and earns an extra income. 

Margaret seeks a loan to help her pay school fees for her child. She has a vision of owning a big salon in the next five years and even quitting her employment.

loans.use: to pay school fees for her child.

loans.name: Levan

texts.en:
Levan is 58 years old. He lives in a small village of Dolikauri with his wife, Lamara. Levan requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for a family business start-up, but without any success. His loan request was rejected all the time because of his low income and the family’s poor living conditions. 

The main source of the income for the family is from agricultural activities. The own a vineyard and also have beehives with bee colonies, rabbits and milk cows. The cow are milked every day to produce dairy products. The family also produces honey. All the products are sold at the local markets and the family gets a small monthly income. 

Levan requested a loan from Credo to start-up a family business. Levan has now been approved for a loan within the framework of the new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to rural poor people, who do not have access to credit products. These rural poor people are regarded as “high-risk borrowers” because of their low income. 

With his credit, Levan will purchase chicks, chicken feed and cages for them. He will grow chicks and sell hens at a higher price. With his new business, Levan will expand the agriculture he has and increase the family income. With the increased income, he will be able to look after his wife better and insure better living conditions for her.

loans.use: To purchase chicks, chicken feed and cages for them.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a motorcycle for community health work

loans.name: Sibusisiwe

texts.en:
Greetings from Zimbabwe! This is 42-year-old Sibusisiwe. She operates her business in Bulawayo. She is a single parent and has two children. 

Sibusisiwe runs a flea market business, which sells a variety of clothing and footwear items. She sells clothes for kids, women and men, as well. She also sells footwear. The business has been in operation for over two years now. She says the main challenges she faces are lack of adequate working capital and high rent for her premises. 

She has requested a loan of $500. She wants to use the money to replenish her stock, as well as buy winter wear, since the season has changed. She will buy clothing items ranging from as little as $1 to $50, and resell at between $5 and $100. She says the extra income generated as a result of this loan will allow her to cover her household expenses and rental, pay her kids' school fees, as well as increase the business capacity. 

In the future, Sibusisiwe plans to have a clothing boutique in the Central Business District as well as more stalls in the flea market.

loans.use: to order stock of kids' clothing, ladies' clothing and menswear.

loans.name: Adriana María

texts.es:
Adriana es una mujer de 32 años de edad, es madre de un hijo de cuatro años, y la mayor parte del tiempo ha residido en el campo en donde se dedica principalmente al cultivo de café, actividad que se ha convertido en su fuente de ingresos para el sostenimiento de su familia. En la actualidad se encuentra solicitando un crédito que invertirá en la compra de insumos como fungicidas, abonos e insecticidas. Con el fin de mejorar su cultivo y sacar una cosecha de mejor calidad.
Su mayor sueño es sacar su hijo delante y garantizarle mejores condiciones de vida.
texts.en:
Adriana is a 32-year-old woman, and the mother of one 4-year-old son.  The majority of her time has been spent in the countryside where she makes a living primarily by growing coffee; work which has become the main source of income for supporting her family. 

Right now she is asking for a loan to invest in the purchase of supplies like fungicide, fertilizer, and insecticide, with the goal of improving her crop and getting a better quality harvest.  Her greatest dream is to get her child ahead in life and to guarantee better living conditions.

loans.use: to buy supplies (fungicide, fertilizer, and insecticide).

loans.name: Varlam

texts.en:
Varlam is 46 years old. He lives in Samtredia district with his wife, Lia, and two children (19 and 22 years old). Varlam requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for family business start-up, but without any success. His loan request was rejected all the time because of his low income and the family’s poor living conditions. 

The main source of income for the family is from agricultural activities. In particular, they have two milk cows and three calves. The cows are milked every day to produce cheese. The product is sold at the local market, and the family gets a small monthly income of 200 Lari. Their additional income is Varlam’s son’s salary. He is an artisan and works on house construction and renovations for private orders. 

Varlam requested a loan from Credo to start-up family business. Varlam has now been approved for a loan within the framework of the new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages provision of business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to rural poor people, who do not have access to credit products. These rural poor people are regarded as “high-risk borrowers” because of their low income. 

With his credit, Varlam will purchase a truck. He will be working on private orders as a driver to transport different types of cargo. Varlam will earn additional income for the family. He wants to expand his agriculture and improve the family's living conditions. For this reason, he will work as hard as he can and try to do his best in the new business.

loans.use: To purchase a truck.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a motorcycle for community health work

loans.name: Morrison Gatumu

texts.en:
Morrison is a father of four, one boy and three girls, and a grandfather of three.  Two of his children are still in high school but the older two girls dropped out due to lack of school fees and now live with him and their children.  The family depends on their 3-acre piece of land for agriculture and dairy farming to get income for their basic needs.  Morrison, who is the head of the family, has to educate his two children in school as well as help take care of his 3 grandchildren from the little that comes out of his farming business. 

Through hard work, he has bought 3 dairy cows with an earlier Mifugo loan advanced to him by Visionary Empowerment Programme and from these he is able to sell at least 20 liters of milk per day at about 25 US cents, making around $140 per month.  For the last 6 months he has also been using composting to grow vegetables for sale and makes an extra $23.

However, a big percentage of this money goes into purchase of fuel which he can save by using renewable energy.  By having a biodigester constructed for him, he can save at least $16 spent every month on charcoal, $35 spent on kerosene, and the drudgery his wife and girls endure while searching for firewood.  With the bioslurry, he can also improve his agriculture by using higher quality manure, hence increasing his crop production and in the end increasing his income.  The increased income and the savings from fuel purchase will enable him repay the loan and have an improved lifestyle for himself and his family.

loans.use: to construct a biodigester

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.es:
La cliente vive en Guayaquil, ella es una mujer emprendedora ya que comenzó con su negocio de venta de ropa por catalogo hace 5 años atrás y asi poder ayudar a su esposo con los gastos del hogar. 

Poco a poco fue mejorando sus ventas, hasta ahora que tiene una cartera de clientes fijas que le da a crédito en ocasiones. Trabaja desde las 08h00 am hasta las 18:00 pm. Lo que le dificulta a ella realizar sus actividades con normalidad es que tiene que cuidar a su hijo que tiene una discapacidad de aprendizaje. 

Para seguir con su negocio ella quiere comprar con el préstamo ropa por catalogo para mujer y hombres y asi tener mas diversidad en su mercaderia.
texts.en:
The client lives in Guayaquil.  She is an enterprising woman who started her business of selling clothes by catalog five years ago.  This way she is able to help her husband with the household expenses.

She has been improving her sales little by little.  Now she has a portfolio of fixed customers to whom she sometimes gives credit.  She works from 8:00 a.m. until 6:00 p.m.  What makes it difficult for her to do her business activities normally is that she needs to care for her child who has a learning disability.

In order to continue with her business she wants the loan to buy women’s and men’s clothes by catalog.  This way she will have a greater variety of merchandise.

loans.use: to buy women’s and men’s clothes by catalog.

loans.name: Consolata

texts.en:
Consolata is a single mother of 2 girls, one in high school and the other in primary school.  She is an entrepreneur selling electronics and cereals to sustain her family.  Being a member of one of our groups, she has been on the forefront to promote solar energy through educating other women and referring them to Visionary Empowerment Programme for purchases. 

To empower her, we have advanced her this loan to stock her shop with a variety of solar lamps that she can use for demonstration and also sell to make a profit and  grow her business.  This will make the lamps even more accessible to the clients who will no longer need to pay transport to come collect the lamps from our storage.  From the lamps she will make a profit margin of between $2-35 US and this will enable her repay the loan as well as plough some money back into the business for growth.

Being a very influential person in the community, she will be able to reach bigger numbers at the bottom of the pyramid as most people have confidence in her.  Demonstrations in the evenings when its dark will also help increase the confidence in the solar lamps which have passed the Lighting Africa standards test of quality.  Our motivation is that by empowering Consolata, we will have secured her girls’ education and ensured a better future for them.

loans.use: To purchase solar lamps for resale

loans.name: Maria Natividad

texts.es:
María reside en la ciudad de La Libertad – Ecuador, en sus inicios hace ya muchos años vendía pescado recorriendo las calles, de esta manera se dio a conocer y logro tener muchos clientes.

Con el paso del tiempo aprendió que se debe brindar una buena atención a los clientes y entregar productos frescos, de esta manera con mucha disciplina logra ubicar su negocio en un local dentro de un Mercado Municipal de la ciudad, donde actualmente atiende personalmente a sus clientes. 

Es por eso que decidió realizar un préstamo en Banco D-MIRO porque ahora desea tener su propio equipo de frio para almacenar los pescados y mariscos.
texts.en:
María lives in the city of La Libertad, Ecuador.  The beginning of her story took place many years ago when she sold fish by traveling through the streets.  This was the only way she knew how and was able to gain many customers.  As time passed, she learned how to provide good service to her customers and deliver fresh products to them.  With great effort, she set up her business at a stall in the municipal market in her city.  She currently attends to her customers personally.  

For this reason, María decided to request a loan from Banco D-MIRO because she wants to have her own chilling equipment for storing fish and shellfish.

loans.use: to purchase chilling equipment for storing fish and shellfish

loans.name: Gregorio

texts.es: El Sr. Gregorio reside en la ciudad de La Libertad – Ecuador, inicialmente hace algunos años vendió alitas de pollo y chuzos asados, después de varios meses al tener clientes fijos le recomendaron que se ponga un restaurante, es así como se las ingenio para modificar un poco su casa e instalo su local donde actualmente tiene un restaurante, esto ha sido el producto de mucho sacrificio y esfuerzo no solo de el sino también de su familia ya que su esposa forma parte de esta micro empresa  que cada vez sigue prosperando,  se decidió a realizar un préstamo en Banco D-MIRO porque ahora desea tener otro restaurante pero esta vez en el centro de la ciudad y asi tener mas ingresos para darle lo mejor a su familia.
texts.en: Gregorio lives in the city of La Libertad, Ecuador.  At first, some years ago, he started selling chicken wings and kebabs.  After some months, when he had gained some regular customers, they recommended that he set up his own restaurant.  This is how he came to modify his house and set up a space there for his restaurant.  This took a lot of effort and sacrifice on his part, and also on the part of his family, since his wife is part of this small business, which is now continuing to prosper.  Gregorio decided to take a loan from Banco D-MIRO because now he wants to have another restaurant, this time located in the center of the city, to earn better incomes to support his family.

loans.use: to buy mass market consumer goods

loans.name: Tekoporave Rekavo Group

texts.es:
El grupo llamado Tekoporave Rekavo está en su ciclo número  2 del programa de comité de mujeres, el grupo lleva ese nombre, ya que Tekoporave Rekavo significa en busca de una nueva manera de vivir,  eso es justamente lo que ellas están buscando.
La Sra. Mirna es una de las integrantes, ella es manicurista y cuenta que está creciendo gracias a su trabajo y esfuerzo, ya que se ha hecho de muy buena clientela que siempre le pide sus servicios, sabe hacer todo tipo de diseños en uñas y esculpirlas y es por eso que le está yendo muy bien.
Solicita su crédito para la compra de esmaltes, quita esmaltes, algodones, apliques para uñas, entre otras cosas para su negocio. Y de esa forma poder seguir creciendo con su negocio y dar así a su familia lo que necesitan para tener una vida sin privaciones.
texts.en:
The group called Tekoporave Rekavo is in its second cycle with the women’s group program. The group chose its name because “Tekoporave Rekavo” means to be in search of a new manner of living, which is exactly what they are searching for.

One of the members, Mirna, is a manicurist and says that business is growing. Thanks to her hard work and effort, she has accumulated a good clientele that always request her services. She knows how to make all kinds of designs on nails and sculpt them, so everything is going very well for her. 

She is requesting the loan to purchase nail polish, nail polish remover, cotton balls, and nail applicators, among other things she needs for her business. This way she will continue growing her business and provide her family what they need so they can live a life free from deprivation.

loans.use: purchase nail polish, nail polish remover, cotton balls, and nail applicators

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.es:
La cliente vive en el sector del Paraiso. Comenzó su negocio de venta de productos personales cuando le conversaron de hay compañía que daban productos a crédito. Ella comenzó invirtiendo una cantidad pequeña de dinero poco a poco fue mejorando sus ventas. 

En la actualidad vende cosméticos. También ha podido con un dinero que tenia ahorrado invertir en un pequeño restaurante donde vende almuerzos. Poco a poco esta mejorando sus ingresos ya que ella es madre soltera. Tiene un hijo que estudia en una escuela fiscal. Una de sus dificultades es que tiene una discapacidad que le impide trabajar al 100%. 

Con el préstamo quiere comprar cosméticos, perfumes, cremas, víveres para vender almuerzos y así mejorar la mercadería que vende a sus clientes.
texts.en:
This client lives in the El Paraíso sector.  She started her business selling personal use products when they told her that there was a firm that would give her the products on credit.  She started investing small amounts of money and gradually improved her sales.  She currently sells cosmetics.  

She’s also been able to use some money she had saved to invest in a small restaurant where she sells lunches.  Gradually her income has been improving since she’s a single mother and has a son attending public school.  

One of her difficulties is that she is handicapped so she’s unable to work at 100%.  She wants to use the loan to buy cosmetics, perfume, cream and foodstuffs to sell lunches and to improve the merchandise se sells to her customers.

loans.use: to buy cosmetics and basic food staples.

loans.name: Elizabeth Waithira

texts.en:
Elizabeth is a member of the Happy Mothers Group based in central Kenya.  Just like their group name, Elizabeth is one of the many happy women who have benefitted from affordable credit to purchase renewable energy products.  Like other women, she wants to improve her life by saving money spent on purchasing kerosene and charcoal.

She has applied for this loan to buy 2 solar lamps so that when she is using one in the kitchen, her children can use the other to do school assignments in the sitting room.  She can also use the same lamp in the morning when she wakes up at 4:00am to milk her cows.  In addition, she also bought an energy-saving charcoal Jiko that will enable her to save at least 50% of the charcoal she uses with the traditional charcoal Jiko, as well as reduce the carbon emissions that give her a headache.

By using the lamps and the energy-saving Jiko, she will be able to save at least $31 US and with this, her salary from her casual employment, plus the savings from milk sales she will be able to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy solar lamps and an energy-saving Jiko

loans.name: Patacocha  (Cuenca) Group

texts.es:
El banco comunal Patococha está formado por 2 socios y 10 socias quienes viven por la parroquia Victoria del Portete en Cuenca, lugar que goza de grandes llanuras y está rodeada de montañas, su arquitectura es una mezcla de lo natural y lo antiguo. Su gente  aun mantienen vivas la cultura y tradiciones de sus pueblos, la gastronomía es muy variada, sus actividades principales es la crianza de ganado, la agricultura y muchos laboran en la ciudad en diferentes actividades.

Una de las socias de este grupo es la Señora. María Gricelda, tiene 53 años de edad, es divorciada pero en su unión conyugal ha concebido 6 hijos, cinco de ellos son casados y viven independientes, su único hijo soltero estudia en una universidad de la ciudad, la casa en la que vive es propia.

Doña María Gricelda se dedica a las tareas del campo como, cría animales y a la agricultura que por el momento le va muy bien, este su método de vida que le ha permitido mejorar la estabilidad económica de su hogar y a podido sacarle adelante a sus hijos. 

El dinero de su crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de cerdos, pollos, cuyes y alimento para animales. El grupo de crédito le gusta porque siempre cuenta con el apoyo de sus compañeras en algún momento difícil.
texts.en:
The communal bank Patococha is made up of two male members and ten female members who live in the parish of Victoria del Portete in Cuenca. This place features vast plains and is surrounded by mountains. Its architecture is a mix of the natural and the ancient. The populace keeps the culture and traditions of their villages alive, and the food is quite varied. The main economic activities are livestock and livestock, and many people work in the city in different activities.

One of the members of this group is María Gricelda. She is 53 years old and divorced, but has 6 children from her marriage. Five of her children are married and living independently, and her only child who is still single is studying in the city university and lives in his own home.

Maria Gricelda is dedicated to farm work, animal husbandry and agriculture. At the moment she is doing very well, and her work is allowing her to improve her economic stablity at home and to help her children. 

She will use her loan to invest in the purchase of pigs, chickens, guinea pigs and feed for her animals.  She likes the lending group because she can count on the support of the other members in a difficult time.

loans.use: to buy pigs, chickens, guinea pigs and feed for animals.

loans.name: Lorena Maribel

texts.es:
La cliente vive en la ciudad de Playas, es una mujer emprendedora ya que tiene un negocio de ropa y cosméticos. Su negocio le ha servido de ingreso para poder mantener a sus hijos ya que ella se encuentra separa de su esposo. 

Ella trabaja todos los dias desde las 09:00am hasta las 17:00pm, tiene un hijo que estudia en una escuela fiscal. Una de sus dificultades para realizar su negocio con normalidad es que ella es pvvs (persona viviendo con vih sida). 

Ella tiene muchas aspiraciones en su negocio por eso quiere seguir trabajando y con el préstamo quiere comprar ropa y cosméticos para vender y tener mas mercadería.
texts.en:
The client lives in the city of Playas.  She is an enterprising woman who has a clothing and cosmetic business.  Her business has served to produce income to support her children because she is separated from her husband.

She works everyday from 9:00 a.m. until 5:00 p.m. She has a son who studies in a public school. One of the difficulties in conducting business as usual is that she is PVVS (a person living with HIV/AIDS.)

She has many aspirations in her business and wants to continue working. She will use her loan to buy clothes and cosmetics to sell and increase her merchandise.

loans.use: to buy clothing and cosmetics

loans.name: Johnny Washington

texts.es:
El cliente Jhonny vive en la zona del Suburbio. El trabaja dando servicio de mecánico. Trabaja desde las 08:00am hasta las 16:00pm. Su trabajo lo realiza arreglando carros. 

Poco a poco a mejorado sus servicios como mecánico de carros, pero como no puede sustentar todos sus gastos en esta temporada que es baja. Necesita comprar con el préstamo para unas medicinas. Esto le ayudara a mejorar su salud y trabajar mejor en su trabajo que le ayuda a sustentar los gastos de su hogar.
texts.en:
Jhonny lives in the Suburbio neighborhood.  He works as a mechanic.  He works from 8am until 4pm. He works in car repair.

Little by little Jhonny is improving his services as a car mechanic, but he can not currently cover all of his expenses because business it's the low season. He will use his loan to buy medicine. This will help him improve his heath, and therefore allow him to improve his work, which will help him cover his household expenses.

loans.use: to buy medicines

loans.name: Tam's Group

texts.en:
Tam was born in 1951. She has a son who is married and is a worker. Tam is a widow. She is a hardworking woman and cooks breakfast to sell. She earns about 3,000,000VND per month. Tam has done this job for seven years. Her challenge in work is that she is lacking business capital. 

Tam's dream is to build a two-storey house. This loan is one of the steps that will help her reach her dream. Tam has participated in SEDA’s credit program since 2006. In the last loan cycle, she borrowed 9,810,000VND and repaid on time. In this loan cycle, she wants to borrow 11,118,000VND to buy more ingredients to cook food and breakfast in the market.

Other members who are part of Tam’s group include the following: 
Phuong, who is 61 years old. She has two children, and is a retired worker. She wants to borrow 11,118,000 VND to sells tonics. 
Diep is 38 years old. She is a farmer and has two children. She wants to borrow 11,118,000 VND to sell beer. 
Mui is 64 years old and has three children. She is a retired worker and wants to borrow 11,118,000VND to make aluminium frames,

loans.use: to buy more ingredients to cook food and breakfast in the market.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth has a retail shop in Kangundo town and has operated it for the past three years. She is also a cash crop farmer. She is 47 years old, married and has four children. 

This is her fifth loan term from KADET LTD and she plans to pay school fees for her child who is in secondary school. The anticipated profits from her business will also be used to pay school fees for her children. 

She hopes to grow her business and make more income and be able to provide good education for her children as well as provide for the needs of her family.

loans.use: to pay school fees for her child and also add some stock for the shop.

loans.name: Demur

texts.en:
Demur is 54 years old. He lives in the small village of Martvili District with his wife, son, daughter-in-law and three grandchildren. Demur has requested a loan from local financial institutions several times for a family business start-up, but without any success. His loan request was rejected each time, because of his low income and the family’s poor living conditions. 

The only source of income for the family is from their agricultural activities. In particular, they have three pigs, six milking cows and seven calves. They produce dairy products to sell. In addition, they have bee-hives with bee-colonies and a plot of land, where nut trees are grown. They sell the harvested nuts and honey at local markets for a good price. It is hardly enough to provide food for the family. According to Credo estimations, the family belongs in the subsistence poor category. 

Demur has requested a loan from Credo to start-up a family business. Demur has now been approved for a loan within the framework of the new joint initiative of Kiva and Credo. The start-up loan program envisages the provision of business start-up and re-startup credits with soft conditions to rural poor people, who do not have access to credit products. These rural poor people are regarded as “high risk borrowers” because of their low income.
